you're all using digital wallets one way or another you may use them to pay for
things whether you're using alipay or you're using tokenized credit cards
you're using digital wallets but wallets are not just used
for payment wallets will be used to prove prove your identity if you want to show your ID
card in the future if you want to show your driver's license in the future you
will use digital wallets if you want to show academic credentials proving where you went to

well if you want access to your car car keys are going to be in your wallet room
keys are going to be in your wallet maybe in the future digital currencies
and cbdcs Central Bank digital currencies they're going to reside in
digital wallets as well so digital wallets are going to be
hugely important we believe they are going to be as important as web
browsers now how are web browsers constructed you can think of web
browsers a little bit like a sandwich at the bottom you have Open
Standards standards like HTML HTTP JavaScript every browser is using those
standards so if this is one piece of bread the piece of bread on top is the actual browser the Google Chrome browser
the Microsoft edge browser the Samsung internet browser they're all based on
these Open Standards but they're also based on open source
software the Samsung internet browser Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge are all
based on blink sometimes called a browser engine sometimes called a rendering engine whatever you call it
it's basically a collection of open-source software even the Safari browser from
Apple is based on open- Source software in this case a project called
webkit so what we're trying to convince you is that it would make sense to
construct wallets the same way browsers are constructed you need Open
Standards on top of the Open Standards you have open source software and on top
of the open source software you have the actual digital wallets and why is that important why are browsers based on open
source Source we see four main
reasons the first one is simply cost if you're all creating software and
you're competing with each other it is cheaper to create that software if we
have shared open- Source components now maybe you don't care about cost you're
not just going to save money but you're going to save time as well if we work
together on some of the fundamental components we're going to be faster and even if you don't care about
money or time there's still two reasons that might be important for you one it's good
for security because the more developers are looking at code the more likely it is
we're going to spot weaknesses in that code and the more likely it is that we're going to patch those weaknesses
before they become problems and if they do become problems we'll be able to
address those problems more effectively if we have a large community uh working
on the Integrity of the code and last but not least it's good for
interoperability because even if we're using the same standards but we interpret those standards
differently we may end up with wallets that are not
interoperable and we need those wallets to be interoperable when you are finishing
your studies in the United States or in Europe or if my children come over to
China to finish their studies we want academic credentials to be able to
travel from one country to another in the future when I come to
Shanghai I want to be able to show a digital wallet with my passport I want to be able to to rent the car and show a
digital driver's license to a policeman none of this is going to work
unless we have digital wallets that are not just secure but that work across
many different countries so in essence we believe that
if we want to retain our ability to travel if we want to retain our ability
ility to study in different countries our ability to order products to pay for
services we need those wallets to work everywhere and open source is in our
opinion the right way to do it with this simple idea we started
seven months ago with 37 members including companies like Accenture and
futureway gen digital T-Mobile the world's largest uh telecommunications company by market cap
and visa for instance the credit card company we recently added Google and
Microsoft as members and we are going to soon announce the governmental advisory
Council which is essentially a body similar to Ian where government
officials are going to join the open Wallet foundation in order to turn it
into a true public private good partnership when I'm not sure are the
the slides working or is it still not uh no no luck today no luck okay

China we're not here to sell you something we're here to
listen we want to understand how to structure open wallet to be a project

the same wallet framework in our opinion so in my personal opinion some of the
projects will really benefit from using the blockchain many projects may not

but then we need to find a way to be able to be compatible to each other and
